events.name: First Meetup
events.description:
Let's have some fun at the one and only Raumstation of Berlin.

Even if the meetup is informal, we have some organizational topics (sponsors, etc.) and we should talk about the upcoming GDD.

events.name: Hands on Go! v0.0.1
events.description:
The second meetup will be a "Hands on Go!" event. That's the result of our first get together. We will enumerate our events with semantic versioning ( http://semver.org/)

"Hands on Go!" means, that we will have talks and do some practical stuff that is indirectly related to the talks or things we do/did with Go.

We should also invest some time in the planning of a first "Go on Boats!". An event where we rent a house boat for a weekend and hold a hackathon.

The "Hands on Go!" events will be sponsored by our soon to be officially announced partners, catering included.

events.name: Hands on Go! v0.0.2
events.description:
Hey Gophers!

It’s almost October and our third meet-up is in the pipeline. We start at 19:00 CEST at SoundCloud HQ.

Our “Hands on Go” events are centered around practical topics like compilers, tools, success stories, pitfalls and anything else that is of special interest for Go hackers.

Talks:

Alexander Surma will be talking about GoBox, a collection of common UNIX utilities written in Go and compiled to a single, statically linked binary. Alexander is the founder of the project and we will get first class, first hand insight and information. Andreas Krennmair will give a talk about cgo, a tool that enables the creation of Go packages that call C code. Andreas uses cgo in some of his open source projects. His talk will be an example driven overview from cgo basics to calling conventions.  One more thing: Alexander Simmerl joined the organizer team. Give him a warm welcome, cookies and a Club Mate ;) He already gave a hand at the September event. Thanks for this!

If you want to help in organizing, improving and growing our user group, just let us know at the next meet-up or drop a message via meetup.com or the mailing list.

We are looking forward seeing you all at Hands on Go v.0.0.2!

events.name: Hands on Go! v0.0.3
events.description:
Hey Gophers!

Happy new year to you!

After a lot eating and sleeping during holidays we decided it's time to get our "hands on Go" once again. So we'll meet at the SoundCloud HQ and will start around 19:00 CET with the meeting.

The agenda is as follows:

* Peter Bourgon gives a demo of goop (http://code.google.com/p/goop/), a synthesizer he is working on. DSP in Go sounds good ;)

* Daniel Bornkessel introduces his getopt package (https://github.com/kesselborn/go-getopt).

* Alexander Surma talks about the latest changes in GoBox (https://github.com/asdf-systems/gobox).

*Alexander Simmer, Alexander Surma and David Lehmann will hold an open discussion about structuring Go projects for go-gb (http://code.google.com/p/go-gb/).

If you want to help in organizing, improving and growing our user group, just let us know at the next meet-up or drop a message via meetup.com or the mailing list.

We are looking forward seeing you all at Hands on Go v.0.0.3!

events.name: Golang Meetup 12.03
events.description:
Hey Gophers!

We didn’t make it in February but hey, Go 1.0 is around the corner and if we are lucky, we can celebrate the release at the March meet-up on [masked]:00 CET.

We are looking for speakers and demos!

The topics so far are:

The new and shiny go Tool. Error handling in Golang In our last meetup and on the mailing list, two more very interesting topics popped up:

The Go compiler family Rust vs. Go If you want to give a talk or demo something, drop the organizers a note on meetup.com or the mailing list.

Alexander Surma is joining the organizer crew. This will help to distribute the workload a little better. Thanks and cheers to Alexander!

We are looking forward seeing you all!
The organizers

events.name: Golang Meetup 12.04
events.description:
Hey Gophers!

Our next get together is scheduled for Thursday, [masked]:30 CEST.

If you want to give a talk or demo something, comment this event or send a message to our Google Group.

We are looking forward seeing you all!

The organizers

events.name: Gopher’s new Frame
events.description:
Dear Gophers,

it’s been a while! A lot has been going on, a lot has changed in World of Go™, a lot has to be discussed.
 Our next meetup is scheduled for September 27th 7.00pm at c-base[1]. That’s right, at c-base. This event will be rather informal, so we thought something less office-y and more bar-y might be appropriate.

We want you guys to think about what your expectations of a Go User Group are. What would you like to focus on? Do you want to know the in-depth workings of the Go language? Do you want to discuss design problems in your current project with fellow Gophers? Do want to inspect the newest libraries from the golang-weekly[2] mailing list?
Whatever it is, we want to know. We have ideas of our own, but it is important to us that those ideas are what you like to hear. Nobody likes a waste of time.

Please RSVP and we are looking forward to seeing the old and a lot of new faces :)
The Go User Group Organizers
 PS: This is also available as a Google+ Event: https://plus.google.com/events/cn0bfu3khsm83l0r1cp4fgmbcp4<a>
</a> [1]: http://www.c-base.org
[2]: https://groups.google.com/group/golang-weekly

events.name: October Meetup
events.description:
Hey Gophers!

Let’s come together for our next meet up. It’s scheduled for the 23rd of October 19:00 CEST at the one and only c-base.

As we’ve established last time, you should be in control of the content. We came up with three basic ways of achieving this:

You discovered a library which you consider useful and worthy of deeper inspection and want to introduce it You wrote a library or application and want to collect feedback and be “roasted” You want to give an introduction of a language feature `Struct tagging` seems to have struck a nerve at the last meeting and we would like someone to prepare a talk on this topic. Both, the user and the developer side should be covered.

If you want to help out and give a talk or present something, drop the organizers a note or leave a comment on this post.

Cheers,
The Organizers

events.name: A Gopher from the southern hemisphere
events.description:
Hey Gophers!

In November we have a very special treat for ya: Andrew Gerrand from Google’s Go team in Sydney will be joining us in Berlin for our meetup.

Our event will be held at SoundCloud HQ, where Andrew will talk about Go and its ability to grow with grace. The talk should be of interest to both language newcomers and experienced programmeres and will show how a simple implementation evolves into a “chat roulette”-like web-application.

Whilst also sponsoring our Pizza, SoundCloud will hold a talk themselves about how they use Go internally and why they call it Bazooka.

So mark the 14th of November in your calendar and spread the word!

 

See you then,

the organizers.

events.name: The Last Gopher of 2012
events.description:
Hello fellow Gophers!

Our last meetup turned into the biggest Go User Group Berlin Meetup yet. Not only were there 34 Gophers (a 100% show rate!) but a lot of new ones – some of which came from other cities like Hamburg. Thanks again to Andrew for making a stop in Berlin on his tour through Europe, giving an awesome talk and luring in so many new people. Another big thanks to Peter, Alex and Alexis for giving us the inside scoop on Bazooka and Go’s use in production.

Before we all get busy buying last-minute Christmas gifts and plan our New Year’s parties, we thought we’d use the momentum and do another small, informal get-together to round off 2012 and to get to know our new members for which, to our regret, we haven’t had much time to spare last time.

We’ll meet at the infamous c-base at 19:00 CET on Wednesday, December 12. We might order pizza – unsponsored this time, however.

Of course, if somebody has something to show, to roast or to talk about, we’d love to hear from you so we can plan accordingly.

Looking forward to seeing you all,
the organizers :)

events.name: Where Gophers type – Friday, February 8th 0004 A.G. (Anno Gopher)
events.description:
Happy new year everyone!

We hope you had enjoyable holidays and a blast celebrating the beginning of the new year.Last time a lot of interest had been sparked with the idea of comparing GDEs (Go Development Environments). Daniel Hodan (IntelliJ), Andreas Kennmair (vim) and Peter Bourgon (Sublime Text) jumped in.

Alexander Surma presents his latest project. It's a web service for easing the process of import alias creation.

Any other content of unrelated presentations, discussions or code is of course welcome as well. Just give us a short notice.

We got a new sponsor: ProfitBricks is supporting our GDG with cloud infrastructure and catering. Awesome!

We’ll meet – as always – at the infamous c-base at 19:00 CET on Friday, February 8th.

Let’s do this,
the organizers :)

events.name: Shaken, not stirred
events.description:
Hey fellow Gophers,

as this is an informal meetup, we want to keep it short:

We are meeting for drinks at the Trespassers Cafe to sit and talk. If you know Go newcomers, bring 'em along – everyone is welcome. Wifi is available as well.

Looking forward to seeing you all,

the organizers

events.name: I/O Gophers
events.description:
Dear Gophers,

it is time to finally meet again. April was over unexpectedly quickly due to our preparations for the international GDG Summit at Google in Mountain View and the following Google I/O. For that, we apologize.

Conveniently, there has been a lot of interesting content regarding Go at the I/O that we would like to share and discuss with you. If you have something to present, we would love to hear about it as well.

We have not decided where to meet just yet, but we have chosen a date. Our meetup will start on June 7th at 7:00 pm. Please RSVP now. We will announce a location as soon as we have one.

We are looking forward to seeing you all again,

The Organizers.

events.name: Sunshine Gophers
events.description:
Fellow Gophers,

the time for our next Meetup has come. Unfortunately, the people who offered a talk at the last meetup are not able to join us this time. For that reason we have no prepared content as of now.

But, as always, everybody is welcome to join us and present something to get feedback, help or improvement suggestions. At our last meetup this section has been made great use of – to the joy of everyone participating. We would like to continue that and encourage you to just show what you’ve been working on.

If you have something prepared to present, please just drop us a line and we will put you on the agenda.

We will meet on Friday, July 19th at 7pm at the new SoundCloud office. Please RSVP if you plan to come and also un-RSVP if it turns out you can’t make it.

Looking forward to seeing you all,

the Organizers.

events.name: Theory Gophers
events.description:
Hello Gophers,

this month’s meetup we are going to be more conceptual than practical! We are going to meet at the New SoundCloud HQ on Friday, August 16th at 7pm.

Since there seems to be a lot of confusion and it has come up at our meetups in the past, David Lehmann offered to give us a comparison of the theoretical models of concurrency (think CSP, Pi calculus, Actors, etc) and how that plays into the whole Go vs. Erlang debate.

Alexander Simmerl, back in action, will give us an in-depth analysis of concurrency patterns and their respective usage in Go.

As always, we will have our 5 minute presentations, although we will keep an closer eye on the clock this time around.

If you want to have a longer presentation, feel free to contact us.

Until then,

the Organizers

events.name: Gopher Saufup
events.description:
Hello fellow Gophers,

due to our involvement in the organization of this year's Berlin DevFest™, we are unable to prepare proper content for a meetup.

However, we DO want to tell you about our Go-related plans for DevFest and get your feedback. This excuse is good enough to make an informal meetup in a bar, which have been really enjoyable in the past. Brauhaus Südstern even provides WiFi, so we should be all set.

Please RSVP quickly, so we can reserve an appropriate number of chairs.

Looking forward to seeing you all,

the Organizers

events.name: DevFest Berlin 2013
events.description:
The DevFest Berlin 2013 ticket sale has started. We want to spread the word so everyone who is interested in the current state of technology gets the change to buy his ticket.

RSVPs on Meetup *DO NOT* count. If you want to attend, buy your ticket here:
https://berlin.ticketbud.com/devfest-berlin-2013

Looking forward to seeing you there :)

events.name: December Gophers
events.description:
Hello Berlin Gophers,

before this year comes to a frosty end one last GDG Berlin Golang Meetup is in order. Since our last meetup the DevFest Berlin happened and Go turned 4. We will have a lot to talk about.

ImmobilienScout24 was kind enough to offer us their so-called “Casino”, where we will meet on December 9th at 7pm.

If you want to give a presentation, please drop us a line so we can plan accordingly.

See you then,

the Organizers.

events.name: The Elder Gopher
events.description:
Dear fellow Gophers,

here's the official announcement to what has been teasered the last time we met. Andrew Gerrand from Google's Go Team in Sydney offered us to visit Berlin on February 4th, 2014, coming straight from FOSDEM in Brussels. We are very happy about this and look forward to this event ourselves. Andrew will talk about the coming changes and plans for Go 1.3.

Another guest we will have on the stage that night is Felix Geisendoerfer. He is using Go to control a Parrot AR Drone 2.0 over the network and also attempts to replace its original firmware with one that is written in Go.

We hope to draw a big crowd so spread the word and share the event. For the first time we will be meeting at the Google Office Berlin, which will be able to accomodate us with sufficient seats and WiFi.

As always, RSVP if you want to come and un-RSVP if you can't make it. We have a limited amount of seats and a waiting list.

Looking forward to see our memebers and new faces,

the Organizers

events.name: Community Gopher
events.description:
Hello Gopherhinos,

At our last meetup Andrew and Felix drew in a lot of people, both members and newbies. It was a great event in any sense of the word. For comparison: The last time Andrew was here, we had the biggest event until that point in time with 35 people attending. This time around we got a new record: 75 gophers were at the Google Office in Berlin. By now, we are officially the 4th largest Go User Group world-wide.

With this in mind, we want to announce our next meetup! On March 14th at 6pm we will meet at hub:raum, who kindly agreed to host us. The event will be sponsored by Spiffy, who will introduce themselves that night.

Florian Patan will be talking about the IntelliJ IDEA Plugin for Go, what has changed in the past and what's planned for the future.

Dirk Pahl is going to tell us about his production experience with writing backends with Go using different frameworks and solving concurrency problems at scale.

As always, there will be chance to show  side-projects as 5-minute presentations at the beginning of the event.

Looking forward to seeing you all,

the organizers.

events.name: Spring Sauf up
events.description:
Gophers,

spring has arrived and we better welcome it or it might leave just as quickly. That's why we decided to do a sauf up in April.

Our last meetup was very well received, especially our discussion at the end about migrating to Go and how to convince your DevOps. Who says we can't do that over a glass of the drink of your choice?

Since we will be making reservations at the bar, please try to make your RSVP reliable.

Looking forward to seeing you all,

the organizers.

events.name: Hardwired Gophers
events.description:
Hello Gophers,

GopherCon is over and has been a great success. Everybody who went there is probably back by now and it's safe for us to have our next meetup.

Luckily, we already secured the talks for this meetup at last month's bar meetup:

Dirk Jablonowski is going to talk about using Go for hardware development - Tinkerforge, to be specific.

Sergiusz Urbaniak is going to show us how (and why!) to use ACME as your Go development platform.

Our sponsor for this meetup is Onefootball App, who kindly offered us their office space and drinks.

Looking forward to seeing you all,

the organizers.

events.name: Google I/O Extended Berlin
events.description:
This year we'll gather again on board of +c-base spacestation to watch the Google I/O live streams.

Join fellow developers and tech people in watching the sessions and discussing new developments and products.

 

This event is being organized on Google+. RSVPs on Meetup do not count.

Please go here: https://plus.google.com/events/cm5f3ee6siep05tqlgir010ftos

events.name: Ops Gophers
events.description:
Fellow Gophers,

after a busy month with Google I/O and Berlin’s very own Google I/O Extended, it is finally time for the next meetup with Go content.

Posteo kindly offered to host us this time around at their offices. We will gather at 6pm.

Posteo's very own Philipp Bruell will talk about an in-memory database which uses UDP Multicast to distribute its content among the instances.

Peter Bourgon has offered to talk about SoundCloud’s “roshi”, a CRDT set implementation for timestamped events.

Since our last open discussion was very well received, we would like to do another one. The topic of Operations with Go has consistently been brought up and since we have a lot of members who use Go in production, so we figured a lot of experience can be shared here.

See you then,

the Organizers

events.name: October Drink Up
events.description:
Fellow Gophers,

we feel it is time to have one of our beloved drink ups in October.

We have been growing the past few months and there's no end in sight. That is also the reason why this meetup doesn't have a location just yet – we are really uncertain how many people we will want to come. So please RSVP and feel free to invite other Gophers or those who strive to become one.

Once we have established a rough number of attendees, we will look for an appropriate location and announce it here.

Looking forward to seeing you all,

the organizers.

events.name: DevFest 2014 “Building Blocks”
events.description:
Welcome back to the DevFest Season 2014! All around the world Google Developer Groups are creating community conferences and this is yours!

For the 3rd year in a row we, the three GDGs of Berlin, worked together to bring the best of the community together - to share, learn and most of all: have fun!

Supported by great companies like Immobilien Scout - our gracious host for the 2nd time - and Google we are able to provide a great agenda at almost no cost for the attendees.

Please buy your DevFest Ticket here: http://devfest-berlin.de/ RSVP'ing doesn’t mean anything ;)

events.name: Gopher Gala - Distributed Golang Hackathon
events.description: The Gopher Gala is the world's first Go(lang) distributed hackathon. Showcase your skills and compete for prizes against the best Go developers from around the world. The Gala will take place January 23-25, 2015 and is now open for registration. To find out more, check out the website: www.gophergala.com

events.name: Gopher Advocate
events.description:
Fellow Gophers,

DevFest was a great success! Not only was the DevFest a blast to attend in general, but the Go workshop the biggest of ’em all ;) Thanks to everyone who was there!

In February Francesc Campoy will be visiting FOSDEM in Belgium and has offered us to visit us beforehand. If you haven’t seen it yet, we recommend you watch his talk[1] from dotGo. We are very much excited to see what he will talk about and so should you!

Additionally, Björn Rabenstein and Julius Volz from SoundCloud will give an exclusive introduction to Prometheus[2], their OSS Monitoring System.

In other news: The team of organizers has grown and Natalie Pistunovich will help to keep our meetups at a regular pace and will drastically reduce the amount of work a single person has to do in the organizer’s team. Give her a warm welcome!

Then again, one of our organizers, Alexander Surma, has been hired by Google and will move to London at the beginning of March. So if you feel you have the commitment to help keeping the GDG Berlin Golang alive and take Alex’ place, drop us a line or talk to us at the event :)

Best, the organziers™

[1]: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B-r3Wf_I2Lk

[2]: http://prometheus.github.io/

events.name: Know your neighbors
events.description:
Fellow Gophers,  

the January meetup was the biggest so far and we love seeing the community growing and taking the a good spot among the other biggest GDG communities.

Following the interesting intro to the Prometheus project, we would love to hear about other projects growing in Berlin, and so in this month's meeting we'll celebrate new beginnings with a round of lightning talks: tell the community about your project, inspire, get feedback and maybe start new cooperations. 

We will also say a big thank you to our co-organizer Alexander Surma that is leaving us, and a big welcome to Adam Drake that is joining the organising team.

AGENDA:
19:30-19:40 Pizza & beers 
19:40-20:00 Packetbeat / Tudor Golubenco
20:05-20:25 Stock Performer / Oliver Rivo & Luis Alvarez 
20:25-20:45 Short break
20:45-21:05 GoKit / Peter Bourgon
21:10-21:30 Fun with Redis / Paul H. Müller

Our lovely host, offering venue, pizza and drinks, is adjust.

Best, the organisers™

events.name: Know your Gophers
events.description:
Hello Gophers, 

the February-know-your-neighbours meetup was interesting and made us curious to hear about more small local projects.

In the March meetup we'll have another round of lightining talks - share, get feedback and cooperate. Our community is a good place to start showing the world what are you doing, and learn how could you improve it. It doesn't have to be big or advanced for it to be interesting. Sign up here: http://goo.gl/forms/pHlo8iBrq6

AGENDA
19:00-19:30 Snacks & Drinks
19:40-20:00 Go Challenge / Alex Peters
20:05-20:25 Scalability comparison of traditional fork-join-based parallelism / Artjom Simon
20:25-20:45 Short break
20:45-21:05 Gosignify / Frank Braun
21:10-21:30 Kafka - Go client library for Apache Kafka / Piotr Husiatunski

Our lovely hosts this time would be SoundCloud, offering food and beverages. Bare in mind that speakers will get priority to fill out the 10 waitlist spots, so don't be shy!

Special bonus: Gopher for every speaker

Cheers, the organisers™

events.name: Worldwide golanging
events.description:
Hey Gophers,

our April meeting will be extra fun, as we're hosting two speakers from the two edges of the world map.

AGENDA:
19:00-19:30 Food & drinks 
19:30-20:00 Go's generate tool to help write channel pipeline processing code / Ian Hansen 
20:05-20:35 Reproducible builds and dependency management in Go / David Cheney 
20:40-21:30 Free discussions and more food & drinks and  

About our speakers:

Ian Hansen (US) works at DigitalOcean writing Go, working on metrics and logging.

David Cheney (Australia) is a programmer from Sydney. He has been a contributor to Go for several years and together with Andrew Gerrand runs the Sydney Go meetup group. 

Our lovely hosts will be again Soundcloud, y'all know the drill but notice the signs, this time it's in a different room.

About the event sponsors:  
DigitalOcean is the world’s fastest growing cloud hosting provider built for developers. Our mission is simple: we’re passionate about making complex infrastructure simple and delighting our customers with a seamless experience that brings them joy. New users can easily deploy a blazing fast cloud server in 55 seconds with an intuitive control panel interface, which can be replicated on a larger scale with the company’s straightforward API.

events.name: Meet the locals
events.description:
Hey Gophers!

Our meetup #30 was a great event, just two more metopes and we hit a round date!

We had the largest number of attendees so far, got some nice pizza and heard two very interesting guest talks. Seeing the community grow to almost 500 members over less than 4 years is awesome!

In the May meetup we'll continue getting to know the locals and hear about the uprising projects around. One last speaking slot is available, so hurry up to apply and get your gopher!

19:00-19:30 pizza & drinks
19:30 - 20:00 Porting the Barcelona OpenMP Tasks Suite into Go / Artjom Simon 
20:00-20:15 break 
20:15-20:45 Creating a lambda architecture in Go / Florin Patan 
20:45-21:30 networking over drinks

Our host this time, are the Wooga, who will also sponser pizza and drinks.

To give a talk sign up here: http://goo.gl/forms/54YvJT223F
If you have any questions or not sure - reach out.

Bis dann,
the organisers™

events.name: Golang Berlin celebrating a round anniversary!
events.description:
Hey Gophers, 

Welcome to meetup #2^5!

We'll meet in the Google offices on Monday 29/06 at 19:00 - make sure to RSVP with your full name or send it in a DM, so you can get a name badge! 

AGENDA
19:00-19:15 Welcome  
19:15-19:50 Re-writing APIs in Go / Nathan Humphreys
19:55-20:30 Comparison of the Go Scheduler and Erlang Scheduler / Isaiah Peng  
20:30 Networking

About our speakers:
• Nathan Humphreys is the API & Backend team lead at ZenMate
• Isaiah Peng is a Ruby developer at Blacklane

To give a talk next time, sign up here: http://goo.gl/forms/54YvJT223F 
If you have any questions or not sure - reach out.

The plush Gophers who are looking for new homes:

Cheers, 

the organisers™

events.name: Gopher summer fishing school
events.description:
Fellow Gophers,

now that the summer has started, we should all take a break from our coding activities and try fish some gophers. They are known to be seen in the wild in many places and this month we have reports of them being near the sporty office of Onefootball. 

For this meetup, by popular demand, we'll run a fishbowl format: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fishbowl_(conversation)

Here are some of the topics we'll cover: 

• the upcoming Go 1.5 release

• the new, experimental, vendoring approach from the Go team

• how can we, the Go community here in Berlin, grow more and help baby gophers learn and use the language better

• many, many more

If you have suggestions for the topics, please submit them in this document: https://docs.google.com/document/d/10iJKDr7gD0y4PwjrZUr2Gq1Ipwg3SkwCrbQcx2YNxvA/edit (thank you Alex Peters for starting it).

 

Schedule:

- 18:45 - 19:15: Pizza time
- 19:15 - 20:45 Discussions on various topics
- 20:45+ Networking + more pizza

As a prize for active participation in discussions, you'll be able to catch one gopher of your own so don't be shy and join us!

Best, the organizers™

events.name: Gophers summertime
events.description:
Hey Gophers, 

Hope y'all enjoyed the fishbowl session, and are eager and excited towards our very summery meetup, that will take place in the adjust offices, who will also sponsor beers and pizza!

Our very special guest today is Andrew Gerrand, who will talk about Stupid Gopher Tricks, aka fun things you can do with parts of the language, standard library, and tools that people may not be aware of.

About Andrew: I work on the Go Programming Language at Google Sydney. I like clean code, modular synthesizers, MtG, and rabbits.

If you have any questions - just reach out.
The plush Gophers who are looking for new homes:

Cheers,
the organisers™

events.name: Autumn Gophers assemble
events.description:
Hi Gophers,

The time has come for Autumn and for a new GDG Berlin Golang meetup.

Blacklane will welcome us in their office where drinks will wait for us while speakers will dive into their topics.

AGENDA 
* Welcome = 19:00-19:15
* Speaker 1 = Ian Chiles -> Developing Operating Systems in Go
* Speaker 2 = Victor Ruiz -> Colog - a go logging library
* Speaker 3 = Florin Patan -> Debugging Go with Delve (and IntelliJ) 
* Speaker 4 =  Surma -> Go, ray, tracing? Go raytracing? 
* Networking

Do you want to be part of the event? There are two ways: signup and attend or signup and be a speaker! There are still plush Gophers who are looking for new homes.

We encourage everyone to speak about anything Go related and we can also support you with preparing the presentation / tips and tricks so don't be shy and contact us.

If there won't be any speakers around, we can also organize a more focused round of fishbowl with a 2-4 of topics of interest that you can propose.

To give a talk next time, sign up here: http://goo.gl/forms/54YvJT223F 
If you have any questions or you are unsure, don't hesitate, contact us.

Group photo of the plush Gophers who are eagerly looking for new homes:

Cheers, 

The Organizers™
events.how_to_find_us: - The next S-Bahn station is Julius-Leber Brücke (S1) - The next U-Bahn station is Kleistpark (U7) - Just walk into the courtyard, take the right stairs and walk up into the third floor and then just turn right and you'll see the venue

events.name: Golang October meetup
events.description:
Hello Gophers,

we want to hear how are your projects going!

Want to give a talk? sign up here:
http://goo.gl/forms/54YvJT223F 

Want to suggest a fishbowl session topic? add here:
https://goo.gl/lORsp6

Want to adopt a plush gopher? sign up to give a talk

Cheers, 
The Organizers™

events.name: DevFest Berlin 2015 - We are back!
events.description:
IMPORTANT: You need to have a ticket which is available at our event page: 

https://2015.devfest-berlin.de

 Meetup RSVPs are not enough this time!


DevFest Berlin, https://2015.devfest-berlin.de/, is a once a year event organized by the Android, Cloud and Go GDGs from Berlin.

2.5 days of developer happiness with workshops, conference talks and a hackathon - organized and fueled by the community.

You can network with people from the coolest companies around as well as discover new things about your favorite topic. We are looking for speakers so check out https://2015.devfest-berlin.de/blog/call-for-participation/ for more details.

Would you rather attend this time rather than speaking? No worries, registration is open, just make sure you get your ticket in time from here https://2015.devfest-berlin.de/#tickets

Looking forward to seeing you all there.

Have a nice day,
Your GDG organizers of Berlin

PS: Want to save a little more money? Use the offer code GDG-Berlin-Golang_Friends (usable until it's not).

Agenda

Talk 1: TDD in Go / Mat Ryer

Talk 2: Consumer-Driven Contract Testing w/ Pact / Konrad Reiche

About our speakers:

Mat Ryer

Mat has been coding Go before its v1 release (when os.Error was still a thing) after falling in love with its simplicity and elegance. He’s a regular contributor to open-source projects (Testify, Silk, Moq, BitBar) and writes about Go on his blog (matryer.com). In 2015 he published Go Programming Blueprints and is following it up with a Second Edition.

Konrad Reiche

Konrad is a backend developer at tape.tv working on a video livestreaming platform in Go, mainly implementing microservices with Go Kit. Before that he worked two years in London for an audio streaming company. His first Go application was jukebox powered through Slack on a Raspberry Pi.

Cheers,

events.name: Christmas Gophers - last meetup for 2016
events.description:
Hey Gophers, 

Welcome to our final Meetup for the year!

If you'd like to join the streaming of the event -  we'll publish instructions on the day of the meetup.

If you'd like to give a talk and get a plush gopher - submit your talk here.
If you'd like to suggest topics for the fishbowl session - submit your topic here.

Agenda

19:00-19:25 drinks, pizza and networking

19:25-20:10 Welcome & Talk 1
Note: streaming in our remote speaker for this talk

Code, CI, Infrestructure - the Gophers Way / Alex Baitov

Golang becomes pretty powerful. There are plenty of everyday Golang tools. I will show you that we built infrastructure mostly consists of tools written on one language - Golang. What benefits did we gain from writing an application on the language of its infrastructure. And I will describe how we use Golang in production at 2GIS. 

20:10-20:20 Announcements, HR lost and found and break

20:20-21:00 Talk 2

Golang at Travel Audience / Andreas Krennmair

Hear what about the real-time aspect of Go, the RTB log collection and processing, how we collect profiling data from the bidders, store them as metrics, and use that to get alerts on inefficient code.

21:30-22:00 Talk 3

Profiling Production Go Applications with StackImpact / Dmitri Melikyan

Optimizing application performance or finding the root cause of a performance issue in production Go applications requires continuous execution insights, such as hot spot and bottleneck location with line-of-code precision. In this talk I'll show how to profile and monitor Go applications in production using StackImpact profiler.

About our speakers:

Andreas Krennmair, TravelAudience

Andreas is a software developer at travel audience, where he has worked on multiple Go applications including advanced real time use cases. He has used Go for private projects since late 2009, and professionally for about 3 years

Alex Baitov, 2GIS

Alex is a senior backend developer at 2GIS, an international tech company, developing software for convenient city living. The main product, 2GIS City Information Service, is currently used by over 40 million people. Alex worked with php, javascript, python, go, scala, and aims to widen and deepen his of knowledge programming languages, team leading, networking, continuous integration/delivery/deployment and software architecture. He tries to take different points of view and wants to share with you his investigations.

Dmitri Melikyan, StackImpact

Dmitri is a software engineer building, profiling and monitoring products for the last several years. He is the founder and & CEO of StackImpact.

Cheers,  

The Organizers™

If you'd like to give a talk - submit your proposal here.

Agenda

19:00-19:30 Drinks, snacks and networking 
(yes, this includes details about the go 1.8 release party we will throw)

19:30-20:15 Talk 1 

gobpf - Utilizing eBPF from Go

eBPF is a Linux in-kernel virtual machine that is used for tracing kernel functions, networking, performance analysis and more. In this talk I will give an introduction into eBPF and gobpf, a new library under the IO Visor Project, and show how gobpf can be used to access and utilize eBPF features from Go programs. We will also look at the design of gobpf and its use of the bcc framework and Cgo.

20:15-20:30 Announcements, HR lost and found and break

20:35-20:45 An Introduction to Gitea: Git with a cup of tea, what it is, and why we forked - Mathias Loibl

Michael Schubert, Kinvolk

Michael is a Software Engineer from Berlin where he works on foundational Linux software at Kinvolk GmbH, a Berlin-based Linux development company. Before that, he was working as a Backend and Operations Engineer for a Swiss Infrastructure-as-a-Service provider.

Cheers,

venue.name: Microsoft Berlin
venue.address_1: Unter den Linden 17, Berlin (Entry via Charlottenstraße)

events.description:
Hello Gophers,

Our April meetup is here, and for the event we are having a new host - the Microsoft Accelerator, who will offer us drinks and pizzas!

NOTE: there is a limit of 50 people that will be enforced upon arrival, so make sure to update your RSVP and be there early!

If you'd like to give a talk - submit your proposals here.

If you'd like to suggest topics for the fishbowl session - submit your topic here.

If you have more ideas - talk to us at the Gophers slack in the #berlin channel and follow us on twitter!


Agenda

18:30-19:15 networking over drinks and pizza

19:15-19:30 Welcome words

19:30-20:00 Making AI Easy with Cognitive Services / Nicoleta Mihali

Cognitive Services is a set of ready-made machine learning APIs that allow you to breath intelligence into your application using only simple HTTP calls. In this talk, you will be introduced to the Microsoft Cognitive Services APIs and see how you can use them together with the Go programming language to transform your application. In addition, Go has rich support for concurrency, which enables you to perform a large number of API calls simultaneously (e.g.,face detection and identification, emotion recognition, OCR).This is about the power of machine learning at the end of an API call.

20:00-20:30 Announcements, HR lost and found and break

20:30-21:00 Semantic Addressing Extension for Go's net Package / Philipp Brüll

21:00-end Networking

About our speakers

Nicoleta Mihali (@nikk_mihali) is a Technical Evangelist with Microsoft Germany with a focus on natural user interaction technologies, like Cognitive Services, Bot Framework, Cortana and Kinect. She works with developers on designing and building intelligent applications. Prior to joining Microsoft, she studied Computer Science and Human-Machine Interaction, and worked in the automotive industry.

Philipp Brüll is a language agnostic developer at simia.tech

Cheers, 

The Organizers™

events.description:
Hello Gophers,

June is here and so is the June meetup!

*There will be a cap of 70 at the door, please RSVP accordingly*

This month we have a very special speaker from abroad, a new hosting company and a discount code for dotGo ( https://dotgo2017.eventbrite.com?discount=GOBERLIN ).

If you'd like to give a talk - submit your proposals here ( http://goo.gl/forms/54YvJT223F ).

If you'd like to suggest topics for the fishbowl session - submit your topic here ( https://goo.gl/lORsp6 ).

If you have more ideas - talk to us at the Gophers slack ( https://gophersinvite.herokuapp.com/ ) in the #berlin channel and follow us on twitter ( https://twitter.com/gdgberlingolang )!

Agenda

18:45-19:15 networking over drinks and pizza

19:15-19:30 Welcome words

19:30-20:00 githubql - a Go Client for GitHub GraphQL API / Dmitri Shuralyov

githubql was the first Go client library for a GraphQL API (as far as I know). Creating it required answering questions like: What does a Go client for GraphQL look like? Is it even possible? What is a good API design? This talk will describe the thought process, decisions made, and trade-offs encountered. As featured in the Golang Weekly newsletter ( https://golangweekly.com/issues/162 ).

20:00-20:30 Announcements, HR lost & found, break

20:30-21:00 Go away: HTTP load shedding / Rob Vollmert

How do you keep your web app responding swiftly when you have more requests coming in than you can handle? In this talk, Rob presents our approach for handling request shedding in Go, developed for a real-time bidding platform.

21:00-end Networking

About our speakers

Dmitri Shuralyov is a software engineer who comes from a C++ background, and has fully switched to Go since 2013. He spends time working in the world of open source Go packages, contributes to the Go project, GopherJS, and other Go initiatives.

Rob Vollmert is senior backend developer at DCMN. He has a PhD in mathematics from FU Berlin and is a world champion in logic puzzles. He has 5+ years of experience in Go, C, Haskell and other languages. Rob is also the maintainer of the blog https://maybepuzzles.wordpress.com/ ( https://maybepuzzles.wordpress.com/ )

Cheers,

The Organizers™

In this talk we will look at ETL pipeline (inspired by Logstash), built by Christian, which helps him to wrap his head around the extraction and processing of information from a Docker Engine to provide useful metrics,events, logs and inventory (MELI) from containerized environment.

21:00-end Networking

About our speakers

Tomás Senart is a Gopher at heart for more than 4 years. Since 2017 he has been pushing the envelope to bring the best of OptioPay's Engineering out to the world. His path through companies such as Apple, SoundCloud, Thomson Reuters and Mesosphere has led him to what he is today: An Engineering Leader, Software Architect, Public Speaker, Mentor and OpenSource contributor: https://github.com/tsenart

Christian Kniep got bored with the small pieces after 10 years journey, rooted in the HPC parts of the german automotive industry. He became the InfiniBand go-to-guy while operating a crash-test cluster and pivoted to the R&D department of Bulls BXI interconnect. When told at a conference that HPC can not learn anything from the emerging Cloud and BigData companies, Christian became curious and is now leading the containerization effort at Gaikai Inc. (company behind Playstation Now).

Cheers,

The Organizers™

Missed Gophercon? Never fear! This talk will run through the highlight reel and behind-the-scenes of what went down in Denver. Stay on to make your first contribution to golang core and get a walkthrough of Gerrit, the Git workflow that Google uses.   

This is a hands on workshop, so make sure to bring your laptop!

19:30-20:00 Go at home24 / Tuna Celik

20:00-20:30 Announcements, HR lost & found, break

20:30-21:00 Making Code Write Itself: How To Build Code Generation Tools in Go / Bouke van der Bijl

As a long-time user of Go, I am a huge fan of how its built-in templating system is powerful and easy-to-use. However, it’s far from perfect: it can be slow and failure-prone because it interprets templates at runtime. A better solution would be a statically compiled template that combines the benefits of writing code by hand, while also being simple and fast to use.

Rather than creating yet another templating system in Go (did we need another one?) I took this as a learning opportunity to write a static compiler for Go templates. The whole process took me about a two weeks, and I ended up creating Statictemplate, a tool that performs static compilation to improve performance, while still supporting all of the Go templating features.

In this talk, I want to show how to use Statictemplate and I also want to share my journey writing it, in hopes of encouraging others into crafting their own tools in Go. Some of the things I’ve learned include:

* How to write a code generator, while ensuring type safety.
* How to statically analyze go types.
* How much faster static code can be compared to dynamically interpreted.
* How to call private functions (don’t tell anyone!).

21:00-end Networking

About our speakers:

Tuna Celik, home24
Tuna is a long time backend developer with a deep and broad background and former CEO and CTO of JAKPARK SOLUTIONS (Turkey). After relocating to Berlin he is currently developing Go micro services for e-commerce solutions at home24.

Bouke van der Bijl, Shopify, @BvdBijl
Bouke is a jack of all trades, master of some at Shopify. He uses Go in his day-to-day work, has written multiple blog posts on the subject, and published multiple semi-serious packages for Go, including one that allows you to monkey patch Go functions (don’t use it).

Cheers,

The Organizers™

events.name: Hacktoberfest in Berlin | RSVP@ http://bit.ly/hacktoberfest18berlin
events.description:
RSVP HERE: http://bit.ly/hacktoberfest18berlin

-----

Happy Hacktoberfest everyone!

Hacktoberfest is a partnership between Digital Ocean, GitHub, Twilio and Microsoft, where we are celebrating open source software during the entire month of October, for the 5th year. Support open source and earn a limited edition T-shirt!

★ The steps are simple ★
- sign up at the Hacktoberfest website (https://hacktoberfest.digitalocean.com/)
- make at least 5 pull requests between 01–31/10 to any public repo on GitHub
- get a Hacktoberfest t-shirt and stickers sent to you!

★ Hacktoberfest in Berlin ★
To celebrate Hacktoberfest in Berlin, Women Techmakers Berlin + the Go User group are getting together on 13/10 at Full Node. Drinks and snacks will be provided!

★ You can come at any time and hack with us. The volunteers of the event will be wearing a special badge - feel free to approach them with questions! It's ok to come for just 1-2 hours.

★ If you need help opening a GitHub account, making your first PR, or any other thing - join us, we will be there to answer your questions!

★ If you are already familiar with contributions on GitHub and just look for a nice environment for your Hacktoberfest hacking - join us!

★ If you want to introduce your open source project for contributions during the event - join us!

★ If you want to give a few hours and help others as a volunteer (doesn't have to be for the entire event duration) - join us!

★ What kind of open source contributions can I make?
New code, bug fixes, translations, proofreading, documentation and anything else you have in mind.

★ FAQ ★

★ Hacktoberfest is an online event open to everyone in our global community, including all genders, levels, professions, etc.
★ It's completely free
★ The Hacktoberfes t-shirt+stickers will be shipped to you by Digital Ocean after the Hacktoberfest celebrations are done, and the team confirmed you followed all the steps
★ If you don't have a project to contribute to, we will help you find one
★ If you can't attend but still want to contribute - you can follow all the steps in your free time, this event is a get-together for the community

★ ABOUT THE BERLIN GO USER GROUP ★

The Berlin chapter of Google Developers Groups for Go was established in 07/2011 and is meeting on a monthly basis since. We love hearing about projects of our members, discuss the language development and network with local Gophers and companies.

Follow us on Twitter:
http://twitter.com/gdgberlingolang

Join us on Meetup:
https://www.meetup.com/golang-users-berlin/

★ ABOUT WTM BERLIN ★
At Women Techmakers Berlin we have been encouraging diversity in tech in Berlin since 2015. We strive for visibility, networking and resources to make the tech community of Berlin inclusive. We are one of the most active chapters of the global Women Techmakers program run by Google.

Our meetup groups are always open to people of all backgrounds, regardless of gender, age, race, expertise, etc. - everyone is welcome!

Follow us on TWITTER:
https://twitter.com/wtm_berlin

Join us on FACEBOOK:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/1106085959408694

And join is on SLACK:
http://slack.wtmberlin.com

20:00-20:30 Announcements, HR lost & found, break

21:00-end Networking

ABOUT OUR SPEAKERS

Alex Simmerl | @xla
Distributed systems at Cosmos/Tendermint, formerly SoundCloud.

Ronna Steinberg | @ronnax
Ronna has been a software engineer for the past 15 years, leads the Berlin chapter of Women Who Go and offers free mentorships to women and gender minorities. A happy feminist who advocates that coding is for everyone.

ABOUT Tendermint | @tendermint_team

The Tendermint open-source project began in 2014 originating from the idea that a distributed consensus mechanism can create a reliable system from unreliable, or unverified parts. The project originally started to address the speed, scalability, and environmental issues associated with Bitcoin. The Tendermint team tackled these cryptocurrency problems using Byzantine Fault Tolerance based “Proof of Stake” to gain consensus and securely maintain the validation of blockchains. A blockchain is formed by a community, or validators, who have the most “stake” in the game. A validators investment and reputation, their stake, are a surety to the validity and security of a blockchain. Tendermint was commissioned by the Interchain Foundation to develop the Cosmos Network, to address the Cambrian explosion of blockchain applications.

Cheers,
The Organizers™

events.name: Go meeetup January: GoDays in Town (no need for a conference ticket to attend)
events.description:
[YOU DON'T NEED TO ATTEND THE CONFERENCE TO ATTEND OUR MEETUP ; DOOR CAP: 120 ATTENDEES]

Hello Gophers,

GoDays (https://www.godays.io/) is in town so let's get together with Women Who Go Berlin (https://www.meetup.com/Women-Who-Go-Berlin/events/257369350/) to hear talks from some cool speakers!

📅 AGENDA 📅

19:00-19:25 Networking over drinks and pizza

19:25-19:30 Welcome words

19:30-20:00 Go Modules: What They Are And Why You Should Care / Ellen Körbes

Package management has been a contentious topic in the Go community from day one. Let's take a look at a potential solution coming out in Go 1.11, called "modules." We'll discuss what they are, how to start using them, check out some examples, and see where they stand against the alternatives. Attendees will hopefully come out knowing whether this feature fits their particular case, and if so, how to implement it.

20:00-20:30 Announcements, HR lost & found, break

20:30-20:50 GRPC for the Web / Luk Burchard

REST and JavaScript pushed JSON as an independent format, making it the de-facto standard for designing web focused APIs. Tools like OpenAPI allow the typing of such API endpoints but are overly complex, hard to reason about, thus often not used. gRPC has proven itself in the backend using typed definitions and code generation. grpc-web allows using gRPC semantics from the frontend to the backend without losing development speed and type safety.

20:50-21:00 Observability in the Kitchen / Daisy Tsang

How can you leverage sensors, open-source software, and Go to improve your kitchen skills? This short talk explores the relationship between bread-making, humidity, and temperature, and how one can use monitoring tools to gain insight into the lively world of sourdough cultures.

21:00-end Networking

🎤 ABOUT OUR SPEAKERS 🎤

Ellen Körbes works with developer relations at Garden. They're a writer, speaker, Go instructor, and Kubernetes enthusiast. A native of Brazil, they're deeply involved with diversity and inclusiveness in tech. http://ellenkorbes.com/

Daisy Tsang is a software developer and writer. She loves open-source software, community work, and learning new technologies. Her non-technical interests include picking up new natural languages, knitting, and baking. https://infoverload.ca

Luk Burchard is a student, software engineer and founder working on improving developer experiences. https://lbb.sh/

🤓ABOUT SysEleven 🤓

As a German ISP, SysEleven takes responsibility for applications to run reliably, efficiently and securely. For this, SysEleven provides a premium technology stack that involves: Managed Cloud Services, an OpenStack Public Cloud, Kubernetes as a Service and Carrier Services – everything exclusively operated in German data centers.

Cheers,
The Organizers™

Code generation is the fifth stage of grief over Go’s lack of generics. With go generate we have a powerful tool to skip writing boilerplate code. Using the ast package I will demonstrate how one file can declare your API, generate middlewares (logging, instrumentation, etc.) and even documentation.

We'll introduce the experimental standard golang geo library (github.com/golang/geo) and talk about its perks and pitfalls. I'll talk about the real world applications and common issues with handling geo data I encountered while handling 100ks of geo points at a mapping startup.

* This talk is for developers who are interested in the emerging-standard geo library and how it can solve problems with complex geometries.

* Attendees should have a knowledge of basic golang concepts.

* Attendees can expect to learn about the concepts behind s2 cells and shape simplification (with Visvalingam's algorithm) and using the standard library to implement them.

🤓ABOUT Fraugster 🤓

Fraugster is a payment security company with the goal of eliminating fraud and increasing our customers’ profits. Over the last years we’ve invented an artificial intelligence technology that combines human-like accuracy with machine scalability. This ability lets us foresee fraudulent attacks before they actually happen and gives us a distinct competitive advantage over every other player in the payment security space. We’re already working with some of the most well-known payment and e-commerce companies in the world. Notable clients include companies like Ingenico and SIX Payments. Fraugster is backed by top-tier investors and is currently managing billions of Euros for its clients.

Cheers,
The Organizers™

events.name: October Golang meetup
events.description:
Hello Gophers,
happy October, we hope you have celebrated well the German Unity Day!

Talk to us at the Gophers slack: https://gophersinvite.herokuapp.com/ in the #berlin channel;

Follow us on twitter:https://twitter.com/gdgberlingolang

📅 AGENDA 📅

19:00-19:25 Networking over drinks and pizza

19:25-19:30 Welcome words

19:30-20:00 Beyond Paradigms / Luciano Ramalho

Is Go object oriented without inheritance? It has closures, but is it functional? The modern approach to learning languages focuses on features, not paradigms. This talk names key language features, how they affect design and coding patterns, and shows in practice how features relate to idiomatic code.

20:00-20:30 Announcements, HR lost & found, break

20:30-21:00 Go and Write Some Readable Code / Grigory Petrov

How often do we say "this code is impossible to change, it should be rewritten"? Sadly, the code in question can be our creation from a few years ago. What can we do to make the code more readable? To address this painful question I will dig into neurophysiology, cognitive intuition and source code, the origin of software complexity problem and how we can deal with it. The talk will follow decomposition, different ways to set navigation beacons within our code, how useful identifiers are crafted and how types are used as traps for future errors. Finally, I will talk about a "gradual" code writing technique that is not limited to a well-known "gradual typing".

21:00-21:30 Panel: Code Readability and Communication / Elena Grahovac, Grigory Petrov, Luciano Ramalho, Bill Kennedy

21:30-end Networking

🎤 ABOUT OUR SPEAKERS 🎤

Luciano Ramalho (@ramalhoorg) is the O'Reilly author of Fluent Python. Principal consultant at ThoughtWorks. Stand-up programmer. Teacher. Game inventor.

Grigory Petrov (@grigoryvp) is a full-time software developer since the late nineties. He was involved in such software projects as Radmin, Advanced IP Scanner, NPTV, Voximplant. A frequent conference and meetup speaker with main areas of interest in software development management and cross-platform development. Works full-time as a DevRel at Evrone, a custom software development and digital artworks company.

Elena Grahovac (@webdeva) is a Lead TechOps Automation Engineer at N26 and a co-host of the GolangShow podcast. With 11+ years of overall experience in IT, she values DevOps culture and passionate about automation, software architecture and site reliability engineering topics.

Bill Kennedy (@goinggodotnet) is a managing partner at Ardan Labs in Miami, Florida, a group of passionate engineers, artists and business professionals focused on building and delivering reliable, secure and scalable solutions. He is also a co-author of the book Go in Action, the author of the blog GoingGo.Net, and a founding member of GoBridge which is working to increase Go adoption through diversity.

🤓ABOUT SolarisBank 🤓

SolarisBank is a banking platform empowering finance pioneers. We've built an API-accessible platform to provide companies with modular building blocks to innovate in finance. As a tech company with a banking license, our business model is strictly B2B2C - we’re focused exclusively on enabling our partners to offer their end customers world class financial products.

Cheers,
The Organizers™

events.description:

Hello Gophers,
Go is 10 years old, let's celebrate!
#GoTurns10

If you'd like to give a talk - submit your proposals here: http://goo.gl/forms/54YvJT223F

18:45-19:00 Shooting the video of #GoTurns10 (details at the #berlin slack channel)

19:00-19:20 Networking over drinks and pizza

19:20-19:25 Welcome words

19:25-19:50 #GoTurns10 Slideshow

20:00-20:30 Talk by Dave Cheney

20:30-21:00 Announcements, HR lost & found, break

21:00-21:30 I wrote 2 lines of Go and they broke things / Emanuele Rocca

This is the story of why and how the CDN serving Wikipedia uses a Go tool for log inspection and metrics gathering. We will see a silly bug that caused memory usage to constantly grow, the way the bug was tracked down with profiling (pprof) and dynamic instrumentation (SystemTap), as well as the fix.

21:00-end Networking

🎤 ABOUT OUR SPEAKERS 🎤

David Cheney (@davecheney) is a software engineer at VMWare. David has been involved with the Go project for more than eight years. He is a regular contributor to the language, focusing on Go on ARM processors. Previously, he ported Go to FreeBSD/ARM and Solaris/AMD64 and is working on a port to Linux/ARM64. David writes frequently about Go on his blog and has spoken locally and internationally.

Emanuele Rocca was sysadmin in 2002, DevOps in 2010, SRE nowadays. While waiting for the next buzzword, I help running Wikipedia's production CDN. Member of the Debian Project for the past 16 years.

🤓ABOUT Zalando Lounge 🤓

Zalando Lounge is an online shopping club for fashion and lifestyle products in 12 European countries. We offer our members daily, time-limited sale campaigns with discounts of up to 75% off the recommended retail price.

We use Go, Java and Javascript to power the sales campaigns where the time and the stock are limited - our members have to act fast in order to get their hands on their favorite items because once the products are gone, they are gone.

Cheers,
The Organizers™

events.description:

📅 AGENDA 📅

19:00-19:25 Networking over drinks and pizza

19:25-19:30 Welcome words

19:30-20:00 The Quest For The Fastest Deployment Time / L Körbes

If a developer changes a line of code, how long does it take for that code to run in their development cluster? L Körbes has seen the answers to that question vary from 1 second to 30 minutes. How can a dev get their team’s code to be on the former side, not the latter?Focusing on Go projects, L discusses the many factors at play: container image layers, Dockerfile hacks, dependency caches, compiler caches, file watching, file syncing, where to compile code, and more. We'll start from the simplest possible setup and increasingly improve on it until the shortest possible iteration time is reached.

20:00-20:30 Announcements, HR lost & found, break

20:30-21:00 Semaphores correctly / Ronna Steinberg

21:00-end Networking

🎤 ABOUT OUR SPEAKERS 🎤

L Körbes does DevRel at Tilt. Having worked at both Garden and Tilt—two of the very few companies 100% focused on the development experience side of Kubernetes—L is immersed in developer-facing issues, and constantly working to solve them. They first got acquainted with Kubernetes while writing code for kubectl, in a SIG CLI internship. They've spoken about Kubernetes and Go at world-famous events, and at countless local meet-ups. L is a proud recipient of a 'Best Hair' award.

🤓ABOUT Awesome Prototype 🤓

Cheers,
The Organizers™

In this talk, we will show how Blacklane redesigned the software architecture used internally to implement our services using Go. This new design involved event sourcing via Kafka, mutations, and data schemas contracts via GraphQL and publish/subscriptions.

20:00-20:30 Announcements, Raffle, HR lost & found

Jose Seravalli is a senior software engineer at Blacklane too and has been developing software for about 16 years now, worked from ERPs, educational software to media streaming. In Blacklane he's using Ruby, Go, GraphQL, Kafka, AWS Lambdas, K8s and Serverless to build distributed applications.

🤓ABOUT Our hosts/sponsors 🤓

Event host:
Blacklane’s mission is to make top-quality global travel reliable and accessible at the touch of a button. We bring peace of mind to the most stressful part of travel: between the front door and airplane gate. Chauffeurs ensure guest safety, efficiency, and comfort across over 50 countries.

19:00-19:25 Networking over (bring your own) drinks and pizza

19:25-19:30 Welcome words

19:30-20:00 Will It Optimize? / Levin Fritz

The Go compiler, like most compilers, will optimize your code to generate a faster executable. But what does that actually mean? How does it change your program? This interactive talk will use a set of short code samples to show when and how the compiler can speed up your Go code.

20:00-20:30 Announcements, HR lost & found, break

20:30-21:00 Semaphores Correctly / Ronna Steinberg

21:00-end Networking

🎤 ABOUT OUR SPEAKERS 🎤

Levin Fritz | Backend Team Lead @ fromAtoB
Levin has been a programmer for eight years, and a Go developer for two. He’s currently team lead for the backend team at fromAtoB.

Ronna Steinberg | Google Developer Expert for Go | Twitter: @ronnax
Architect, speaker, mentor, and a software engineer since 2003, Ronna organizes the activities of Women Who Go Berlin for whom she crafts unique workshops inspired by the industry’s hottest topics. Advocating that coding is for everyone, Ronna runs her own mentoring program for women in tech. Ronna also managed the scholarship programs for GopherCon Europe since 2018.

🤓ABOUT fromAToB 🤓

fromAtoB’s mission is to help everyone find the best way to get from A to B, combining flights, trains, buses and car-sharing. We’re building a platform that integrates and analyses hundreds of routes, stations, providers and prices, using technology ranging from Vue.js, Go and Kubernetes to machine learning and graph theory.

Cheers,
The Organizers™
